postsData.name:
Jonathan M K.
Jonathan M K.
postsData.content:
Iâ€™m happy to share that Iâ€™m starting a new position as Head of GTM Growth at Momentum.io!

I found Momentum and bought it at a past company, LOVED the team and tech. After purchasing, I became a GTM customer advisor giving feedback and having a ton of fun with using some crazy prompts inside of their tech.

This last year, I have had the pleasure of doing some public events with them and leading the AI Advantage webinar series as a GTM Ambassador.

Couple weeks ago,and I had a chat about leading the GTM Growth, marketing, brand ofand even though its not obviously my historical background being in Sales, GTM Strategy and obviously Enablement, it made sense to me and I am so excited.

Not to be too promotion-ee, but for me with work, I have been through a lot and I always look for 3 things with any job which are:
1-Amazing Product, company and trajectory
2-Amazing team and culture
3-Amazing job that I love

I have been blessed to have had some good roles, but not all roles I have had, have hit all 3 of those categories. Transparently, I thought they would at first and eventually, they did not.

is a different beast, here is why:
1-Their leadership and founders are what I call the Trinity of founders.,, andare truly the most talented, smart, emotionally intelligent, forward thinking founders I have yet worked with and how they treat customers is how they treat their team.

2-The team behind them is just as smart, fun, hard working, and inspiring. I LOVE teams where I feel like I need to push to keep up with the talent.. That is Momentum through and through and the team pushes me to be better.

3-The tech. Over the last 2 years, not only have I seen demos of 500+ AI tools, but I have seen a lot of those tools in action when consulting or advising dozens of companies. With Momentum, the tech is the epitome of what AI + GTM should be. Any team on the GTM team, can benefit fromfrom the front line sales rep to the CEO. And the product roadmap is something I am geeking out on as an AI crazy person.

4-My role. Leading brand, marketing, growth, etc. I get to flex all my muscles from leading a product marketing team, GTM Strategy, my MBA in Marketing fromand my AI market and tool awareness as well as my AI knowledge all combined into one. I literally will be paid to play all day with Ai, talking about AI and GTM. Literally dream job.

5-,, and other projects are still ongoing and will not stop anytime soon and thankfully the Momentum team is not only ok with it, but supports it.

I am extremely grateful, excited, and ready for this next step. If your GTM team, sales, enablement, revops, or leaders need help with scaling AI in your team, come talk to me. Happy to show you how to build Momentum (get it ;) with your AI strategy and revenue.

postsData.name:
Neil Sarkar
Neil Sarkar
postsData.content:
I always thought companies had a Sales Problem. Turns out, they had a â€˜People Canâ€™t Make Decisionsâ€™ Problem.

A rep walks into a pipeline review. Their deal is stuck. The prospect â€œneeds more time.â€ Leadership is â€œstill discussing.â€ Meanwhile, the sales manager is staring at Salesforce like it's a crystal ball of doomâ€”"Why do we have so many deals in â€˜Commitâ€™ but not closing?"
Most sales teams donâ€™t struggle to close. They struggle to make buyers realize they need to buy. And when that happens, your CRM becomes a graveyard of â€˜almost dealsâ€™ instead of a tool for predictable revenue. Here are the things that actually move the needle:-

1ï¸âƒ£ They Sell the Cost of Doing Nothing (And Make It Impossible to Ignore)
Your Salesforce pipeline is full of deals that are technically alive but mentally dead. Why? Because reps pitch ROI, but buyers are more afraid of loss than they are excited about gain.
 â€œWe can 10x your efficiency!â€
 â€œYouâ€™re currently losing $500K a year. Every month you delay, thatâ€™s $42K gone.â€
2ï¸âƒ£ They Donâ€™t Sell to the Decision-Maker First (Because Thatâ€™s a Fast Track to Nowhere)
Your Salesforce instance probably has 100+ deals tagged as â€œWaiting for CFO Approval.That CFO hasnâ€™t even opened your email. Great reps equip internal championsâ€”the ones actually feeling the painâ€”to sell for them.

3ï¸âƒ£ They Engineer Small â€œYesesâ€ to Get to the Big Yes
Your deals feel too big and scary to commit. Smart teams break it down:
 â€œLetâ€™s agree this is a problem worth solving.â€
 â€œLetâ€™s align on success metrics.â€
 â€œLetâ€™s run a small pilot.â€
By the time you ask for the big commitment, theyâ€™ve already made it.
4ï¸âƒ£ They Use Reverse Pricing Psychology (So Buyers Donâ€™t Flinch at the Number)
 â€œThis will cost $50K.â€ â†’ Ouch.
 â€œYouâ€™re losing $500K a year. Fixing that costs $50K.â€ â†’ Take my money.
5ï¸âƒ£  They Make Pipeline Reviews Fun (Yes, Really)
Most Salesforce pipeline reviews are glorified autopsiesâ€”a manager scrolling through deals asking, â€œWhy is this stuck?â€ over and over again.
High-performing teams? They turn pipeline reviews into deal strategy sessions:
 Leaderboards for pipeline velocity
 Live objection-handling roleplays
 Win/Loss autopsies that actually teach something
Because if pipeline meetings arenâ€™t helping your reps close, whatâ€™s the point?
With Clientell, AI takes the guesswork out of managing your salesforce. Instead of wasting hours in Salesforce trying to figure out whatâ€™s wrong, your team gets real-time insights and nudges that actually move deals forward.

Takeaway:
Your sales strategy doesnâ€™t need more pressure. It needs better decision-making. Win the right champion, make it easy to say yes, flip the pricing conversation, and stop treating Salesforce as a deal graveyard.
Whatâ€™s one non-traditional sales move that helped your team win a deal? Drop it belowâ€”I promise I wonâ€™t â€œjust follow upâ€ later.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Focusing on decision-making and addressing pain points truly makes a difference in closing deals. What a fresh approach!

postsData.name:
JL Suarez, MBA
JL Suarez, MBA
postsData.content:
Ever tried squeezing a watermelon into a teacup?  That's what handling budget restrictions as an IT leader can feel like! But fear not, my fellow tech maestros, because I've got three surefire ways to make that watermelon fitâ€”without making a mess!

First up, let's talk about prioritization. Imagine you're at a buffet, and you can only pick three dishes. You'd go for the most delicious, right?  The same goes for your IT projects. Focus on those that align with your strategic goals and offer the most value. It's all about getting the biggest bang for your buck!

Next, embrace the power of innovation. Think of it as your secret sauce.  When budgets are tight, creativity becomes your best friend. Explore open-source solutions, cloud services, or even barter with other departments. Who knew your knack for coding could score you free coffee from the marketing team?

Now, let's talk about communication. It's like the Wi-Fi signal of your budget strategyâ€”without it, nothing connects! ï¸ Keep your team and stakeholders in the loop. Transparency builds trust, and who knows, they might even have some brilliant cost-saving ideas up their sleeves!

So, fellow IT leaders, let's turn those budget blues into a symphony of success!  Share your own tips or tales of triumph in the comments below. Let's learn from each other and keep those watermelon-teacup moments to a minimum!
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Prioritization and communication truly make a difference. Excited to hear everyones tips for creative budget solutions! ğŸ‰â˜•ï¸

Marc Mawhinney
postsData.content:
My friend David Barnett and I often get out for a few drinks and laughs at local pubs.

While there, we do the usual â€œshooting the breezeâ€, catching up and talking about whatâ€™s going on in our lives, whatâ€™s happening in the world, and all that jazz.

Although we arenâ€™t meeting in a stuffy boardroom, the conversation always turns to our businesses. Dave is a private transaction advisor/small business deal-making educator and a smart guy (you can check him out at)

After a few hours of tossing ideas around, I inevitably come home with a bunch of them scribbled on a napkin and gung-ho to start implementing them into my business. And I like to think that Dave has gotten some good ideas from our chats as well â€¦

While it might not look like it at first glance, our meetings are an example of a mastermind. Napoleon Hill defined a â€œmastermindâ€ as:

â€œCoordination of knowledge and effort, in a spirit of harmony, between two or more people, for the attainment of a definite purposeâ€.

That means that as long as there are at least two minds helping one another, itâ€™s a mastermind â€“ regardless of the location and even if talking in a noisy establishment playing sports on big TVs covering the walls.

If you'd like to start running your own profitable masterminds, you should joinand I for his live masterclass next week where he'll show you how to do it.

It's called "How to Attract and Keep Clients for 3 Years Not 3 Months", and it's happening on Tuesday, February 11th at 12 pm Eastern - registration link in the comments!

postsData.name:
Carlos Siqueira
Carlos Siqueira
postsData.content:
How I Earned a Spot Among the Worldâ€™s Top 30 Motivational Minds (and What It Taught Me)

Rankings donâ€™t validate greatnessâ€”but they do prove that showing up unapologetically yourself can change lives.

This week, I discovered Iâ€™ve been named # 16 on Global Gurusâ€™ Top 30 Motivational Speakers List, sharing space with legends like Tony Robbins, Mel Robbins, Grant Cardone, Gary Vee, and Simon Sinek (see the full list here: globalgurus(dot)org/motivational-gurus-top-30/). Under comments also.

Humbling? Absolutely. Surprising? Not entirely.

Hereâ€™s why:

3 Lessons From Climbing a List I Never Aimed For

1. Authenticity Over Algorithms

I didnâ€™t chase trends or mimic â€œguru formulas.â€ I shared raw stories of my failures, burnout, and comebacks. People donâ€™t connect with polishâ€”they connect with people.

2. Consistency Beats Virality

One viral post wonâ€™t sustain influence. But showing up dailyâ€”even when engagement is lowâ€”builds trust. This ranking reflects 12 years of imperfect, relentless effort.

3. Impact Isnâ€™t a Solo Sport

Every comment, DM, or â€œthank youâ€ from you fueled this. Your courage to act is the real winâ€”my role was just to hand you the match.

Why This Matters Beyond the Ranking

Being alongside icons isnâ€™t about egoâ€”itâ€™s proof that ordinary people can create extraordinary change without fame or Fortune 500 budgets.

The â€œexpertsâ€ donâ€™t own motivation; you do.

Hereâ€™s My Challenge to You

You donâ€™t need a Top 30 title to lead. Start where you are:

- Host that workshop.
- Post that vulnerable story.
- Mentor one person.

Legacy isnâ€™t built in rankingsâ€”itâ€™s built in the quiet moments when you choose courage over comfort.

Question for you:

Whatâ€™s one fear youâ€™ll push past this week to make your voice matter?

 Letâ€™s unpack it in the comments.




---

P.S. Gratitude to every person who trusted me with their journey. This is your win too.

comments.commentText: Rankings are fleeting, but genuine connection and consistent effort leave a lasting mark. Carlos Siqueira, your journey inspires us all to embrace our authentic selves and ignite change.

postsData.commentAdded: Congratulations on this well-deserved recognition! Your journey inspires others to embrace authenticity and make a real impact. Whatâ€™s your next challenge?

Ani Filipova
postsData.content:
The easiest way for a boss to hide their incompetence? Blame you.

When you succeed -
It is because of their great management skills.

When you struggle -
it's because you are not good enough.

Most donâ€™t even realise their own lack of skill is the real problem.

They never ask, â€œDid I fail as a leader?â€
They assume â€œYou just werenâ€™t good enough.â€

And they slap a label on you: lazy, slow, disorganised, incompetent.

Sound familiar? Hereâ€™s how to know if your boss is setting you up to fail:

1ï¸âƒ£ No Clear Expectations:
Your role feels like a moving target.

2ï¸âƒ£ Lack of Resources:
Youâ€™re expected to win with no resources.

3ï¸âƒ£ Constant Micromanagement:
Every move and decision is second-guessed.

4ï¸âƒ£ Excessive Criticism:
Mistakes are magnified. Wins are ignored.

5ï¸âƒ£ Isolation:
Youâ€™re left out of key meetings and conversations.

6ï¸âƒ£ Changing the Rules:
The goalpost keeps moving.

7ï¸âƒ£ Your Confidence is Crushed:
You start doubting yourself.

Checked off 3 or more? Itâ€™s not just you.

Swipe through the carousel for exact steps to take back control.

 Know someone dealing with this? Tag them below.
 Repost to help others spot the signs and follow me,for career advice that actually helps.

Business Development - The Missing Link Between Marketing & Sales - 540,000 Members Strong
Business Development - The Missing Link Between Marketing & Sales - 540,000 Members Strong
postsData.content:
The BIGGEST SALES MISTAKE costing you $$$: 

Sales is not about tactics or frameworks. Itâ€™s about Persuasion.

Here is one post to learn everything from the most popular book in Sales.

 The 7 Rules of Persuasion:

1ï¸âƒ£ Reciprocity: People return favors. Help first.

2ï¸âƒ£ Commitment & Consistency: If you commit; stick to your commitment, CONSISTENTLY.

3ï¸âƒ£ Social Proof: You follow what others do.

4ï¸âƒ£ Authority: You trust experts.

5ï¸âƒ£ Liking: You listen to people you like.

6ï¸âƒ£ Scarcity: The less available something is, the more you want it.

7ï¸âƒ£ Unity: Shared identity builds trust. Build FOMO.

Now, letâ€™s talk results.

 How I Used These Principles to Win a Skeptical Client:

The Problem: A client didnâ€™t trust outsourcing their lead generation.

The Strategy:

 Social Proof â†’ I showed them testimonials from happy clients.

 Reciprocity â†’ I offered a free consultation to prove my value.

 Authority â†’ I kept communication consistent and showcased expertise.

The Result?

 They signed a long-term contract.

 They referred multiple new clients.

 Their business grewâ€”and so did mine.

comments.commentText: I have the best Nolan story ever. Too long to write out here, but net net, we met at a casual games party (this is like 15 years ago), I didn't know who he was. We talked about cupcakes (it was a Cake Mania party) for like 20 minutes. We debated how many would could eat in a single sitting. Then the room closed in on us. Noticing this, I asked who he was. He told me. That's when he realized the jig was up and he said "Thanks for the chat, guess I'm not eating any cup cakes...see you later." LOL.

Ding! Level Up! HB Nolan!
My favorite Nolan story is when he played the original Tilt World on my iPhone at Casual Connect in 2007 (the iPhone had just launched and no one believed in mobile games.) Nolan said it was fun.  I was on cloud nine for the rest of the week!

Strength in leadership often lies in the ability to bend.

As leaders, weâ€™re often taught to be unyielding, to stand firm like an oak in the face of challenges.

But what if strength lies in flexibility?

Just like bamboo, which bends but doesnâ€™t break
leaders who embrace adaptability thrive in times of change.

The truth is, leadership is about more than just pushing through tough moments.

Itâ€™s about learning to stretch
both physically and mentally.

Regular flexibility exercises, like yoga or simple stretches:
- can lower stress
- boost focus
- and improve decision-making under pressure.

When you prioritize flexibility, you donâ€™t just improve your bodyâ€”you improve your mind.

You become better equipped to handle unexpected challenges
stay calm in chaos, and respond quickly when every second counts.

Dieter Wolf ğŸ–¥ï¸
Dieter Wolf ğŸ–¥ï¸
postsData.content:
On this day in 1986, Steve Wozniak, the co-founder of Apple, stepped away from the company he helped build. 

It was the end of an era; but it didnâ€™t come out of the blue. Itâ€™s thought that Wozniak felt Apple were focusing too much on the Mac while neglecting the Apple II, which was the product that had put Apple on the map.

For business owners, this moment in tech history serves as a powerful reminder: Never lose sight of what made you successful in the first place.

While innovation is important, so is maintaining the trust and loyalty of your core customers. Itâ€™s a tricky dance, but one worth mastering. And itâ€™s essential for sustainable growth.

Since leaving Apple, Wozniak has continued to be a shareholder and occasional advisor while exploring other passions. Many people in the tech world think of him as an icon who isnâ€™t afraid to do what he feels is right, whether it breaks new ground or not.

How does your business strike the balance between embracing new ideas and nurturing whatâ€™s already working?
postsData.commentAdded: A great reminder, indeed! Balancing innovation with core values is key to lasting success. How do you ensure you stay true to your roots?
